Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative: unPAK: undergraduates Phenotyping Arabidopsis Knockouts: A distributed genomic approach to examine evolutionarily important traits
Award.AbstractNarration:
The unPAK (undergraduates Phenotyping Arabidopsis Knockouts) project uses the plant Arabidopsis thaliana to examine how and when differences in DNA sequences lead to differences in traits related to survival, growth, and reproduction. It will detect effects, if any, of mutation in a comprehensive collection of mutants generated by the Salk Institute, and will then compile results in a comprehensive database. To examine the interaction of genetic and environmental effects, unPAK's experiments are replicated within and across multiple growth facilities and labs, and a subset of experiments deliberately manipulate soil factors, moisture, and temperature to see how these important ecological factors interact with genetics.

unPAK will survey enough mutant lines to reach coverage of a third of the A. thaliana genome (approximately 9,000 genes). All data will be uploaded into a public database at arabidopsisunpak.org, and this database of observed traits is linked to existing genomic databases. Evidence produced by unPAK will enable testing central hypotheses about the relationship between genomic features and important plant characteristics. For example, the data can be used to test whether the effects of mutation are predicted by gene attributes such as molecular signatures of selection in the past, gene function, gene family size, or by patterns of variability in natural populations.

unPAK is centered around participation of undergraduate researchers in the lab and the classroom, educating and training undergraduates integratively in genetics, ecology, evolution, and bioinformatics. The network extends across diverse post-secondary institutions, with over 100 undergraduate apprentices participating across 13 laboratories in 3 years. Greater than 20 course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) will be supported by the program, reaching over 600 students. Any discoveries about the influence of particular genes on fruit production, survival, or life history will have significant broader impacts in potential application to crop species.

As a final part of the project the unPAK research network itself is being studied. Using mixed-methods approaches from the social sciences, researchers are documenting interactions among network participants to analyze changes in network structure over time, and to investigate factors that influence student participation and outcomes, including students' accrual of human, cultural, and social capital.

POR.DRECONTENT:
unPAK (undergraduates Phenotyping Arabidopsis Knockouts) is a research project that works with mutants of the model genetic plant Arabidopsis thaliana to test hypotheses about the processes shaping plant genomes and to understand the contribution of genetics to determining the traits of plants. The project engages undergraduates as central members of the research team and evaluates the impacts of participation on their professional development. 

The unPAK project involves a consortium of educational institutions, from community colleges to research universities, and has allowed a large and diverse group of students to engage directly in the research process to make novel discoveries in plant biology and genetics. Over the course of the award, unPAK expanded from a network of 5 institutions to 18 participating institutions. 

The phenotypic database produced by the unPAK network now includes over 500,000 observations of more than 50,000 plants, including mutants in over 8,500 different genes. The database also includes information on whether the mutant lines contain multiple mutations or only a single mutation, which can be useful for other researchers working with these plants. The database includes information on mutants associated with nearly one-third of the genes in the Arabidopsis thaliana genome. In general, the project has focused on traits involving life history, morphology, and reproduction. For example, the effects of mutation have been documented on total fruit production, on architectural branching patterns, and on the size of the plant at the transition to its reproductive phase. The database is freely available at arabidopsisunpak.org.

The data generated by the unPAK project have been used to test a number of hypotheses about plant genomes and the relationship between variation in plant genes and variation in characteristics of the plant. For example, we have compared and contrast patterns of trait variation across different natural populations of A. thaliana with the type of trait variation generated by mutation. We have tested whether mutations in different types of genes affect traits more than others. For example, do mutations in “genetic switches” that turn genes on and off have more of an effect on plant characters than other types of mutations? How does the number of mutations affect characters?  How does environmental variation influence the effects of mutations? The project has yielded a number of publications as well as scholarly presentations at local, national, and international meetings.

The intellectual contribution of the products of the project will allow biologists to:
1) have a better understanding of the relationship between genotype and phenotype in plants
2) identify genes that have potential effects on plant survival and reproduction
3) understand the consequences of environmental variation on mutation expression
4) understand the consequences of the exact mutation position on the phenotypic effects

5) screen mutant lines for the number of insertions for further studies

 

A broader impact of the unPAK project involves training of undergraduates, both in the laboratory and in the classroom. Over 110 undergraduates, including many students from groups underrepresented in the sciences, were trained as research apprentices, learning hands-on skills in plant biology, phenotyping, data management, genetics, and bioinformatics. Many students presented results from their projects at local or national meetings, and upon graduation continued in STEM fields. We developed a new curriculum for teaching skills in data analysis and plant biology in the classroom as part of a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE). We have published this curriculum and made the curriculum freely available at our website arabidopsisunpak.org. These classes were taught over 30 times, to more than 500 students during the project. In addition, the project trained twenty faculty members across the participating institutions and trained a project manager.

In addition, the project is contributing to the social sciences via the study of the ways in which undergraduate participation in the research network influences their access to scientific social capital. The project is also investigating the effect of undergraduate participation in a course based research experience on attitudes toward and retention in STEM fields.

Our research has the potential to improve agricultural production (via discovery of mutations that influence plant survival and reproduction), restoration and conservation of native and invasive species, and to improve our understanding of the effect of development of a collaborative scientific network on social capital acquisition.
